job_title: Information Technology in Woodland Hills, CA
pros: The mission of the organization is amazing.
cons: Low pay. It is a non-profit org.

job_title: Licensed Vocational Nurse (LVN) in Woodland Hills, CA
pros: Union, experienced CNAs, Day and Swing LVNs try to see each other succeed; patient ration for LVNs is 20:1
cons: 1 overnight LVN creates a toxic environment & supervisors do nothing about it; you will get phone calls and text messages at all hours of the day and night asking you to come to work; they will try to pressure you during your shift to work doubles; they will not listen to you if you tell them that you feel something is unsafe; they will verbally reprimand you during your reviews if you have to use "too many" sick days and tell you to call out less; they try to make you find your own coverage if you're sick and either need to leave the shift early or if you need to come in for a shift late; they try to make you provide doctors notes saying you can't work if you're sick and tell them you need to be taken off schedule for a specific amount of time.

job_title: Vice President Human Resources in Woodland Hills, CA
pros: MPTF is over a hundred years old and an industry legend. So many of Hollywood's greats have passed through its gates or lived on campus. MPTF reaches out to the entertainment community to help those in need and provides resources not available elsewhere. It's great to see an organization dedicated to industry members in the entertainment space.
cons: MPTF is a nonprofit 501(c)(3) organization, so as you might expect, budgets are kept tight so that funding can rightfully go to those living on campus or being served throughout the community.

review_title: Don't Apply Here It Sucks The Soul Out of You
job_title: Licensed Vocational Nurse (LVN) in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The union is a plus
cons: Understaffed, too high patient load, too many restrictions and requirements even for part time hours, not paid nearly enough for all the BS

job_title: Registered Nurse in Woodland Hills, CA
pros: benefits, good people, great resources, fair pay
cons: there are no cons that i can think of

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: All the hours you want. Great co-workers.
cons: Covid protocol is a pain.

job_title: Manager in Woodland Hills, CA
pros: It is a steady job.
cons: Senior Management. Lousy Salary and raises. Miss old Management. Lousy HR Department.

review_title: This place is doing down in flames.
job_title: Marketing Manager in Woodland Hills, CA
pros: The campus is beautiful. And working normal work hours 8-4pm was really nice.
cons: Everything. Slow, outdated, ageist, racist. Senior management is a joke. I wouldn't be surprised if this place went down in flames in the next year or so. As a nonprofit, who wants to give money to a bunch of former celebrities with a tone deaf tagline like, "We take care of our own"?

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Studio City, CA
pros: The benefits are  pretty decent
cons: The customer service department needs to clean house, a lot of un experience Managers who don't know there jobs nor have people skills. That department is very unorganized, there's clicks and favoritism. Too many chiefs and not enough Indians. They follow you to the bathroom, talks behind your back and share your business. The wanna be Supervisors/Managers needs to go back on the phone and learn there job. They use there employees to make them look good while they send out emails all day.  The training sucks what little training you get. They call training sitting with another non experience co-worker who talks and eat all day. There Manuel and system sucks. It's like the left hand don't know what the right hand is doing. They only promote there favorite  employees who kiss there butt. The most two faced  back stabbing department in the Company.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Woodland Hills, CA
pros:
Flexibile work schedules, a beautiful campus, and fair compensation (in the non-profit world) make this a great place to work. 
Resources are available for teams when they need them--they aren't afraid to pay for results. 
People who genuinely enjoy working here--groundskeepers, social workers, office employees: many have 20+ years with MPTF. 
Good benefits, an easy-to-access HR department, and management with clear vision and direction for the organization make this a wonderful and supportive work environment.
cons:
Lack of bonuses and other performance bonuses because of the non-profit nature of the fund. 
Some departments are pretty small and may not offer a lot of room for advancement.

job_title: Office Manager in Woodland Hills, CA
pros:
MPTF is such a great place for our residents to live comfortably, but also are taken care of with the greatest staff.  
MPTF and its staff are always making sure that its employees are succeeding in anyway they can. With constant communication with staff,  it keeps us all together and in-the-know of what are company is doing to continue on being a great place to work, but also for our residents.
cons: I don't have any cons I can think of.

job_title: Manager in Woodland Hills, CA
pros: Great coworkers, noble mission, and gorgeous campus.  Really fun and interesting residents--you feel like you're totally part of the entertainment biz, although you're primarily in healthcare
cons: Lots of ongoing change in the healthcare industry

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Woodland Hills, CA
pros: allowed me latitude to seek projects that would help company
cons: management not always receptive to change

job_title: Hospitality Associate in Woodland Hills, CA
pros: friendly staff, easy job in general,
cons: Management sucks, schedule not very flexible, usually short staff
